I think you can describe colors by association with other senses like we do in art. If a blind person asked me what green was I would say sour or gross, that taste in your mouth after you throw up a little is green. One could agregue that plants aren’t those things but I was a curious kid and grass tastes green for sure and there’s a reason some kids don’t like spinach and not to be repetitive but I think it has to do with the gross (green). If they asked me what red looks like I would say hot, angry, spicy 🌶, if blue then I would take them to the beach and let them feel the tide in their feet and say “that is blue” and if they say “blue is cold” I would say “yes.” The only one I can’t really describe too well is hello. Black would be the easiest. Black is nothing, absence of color, and emptiness. Black is a big room with nothing in it with lights off and all you can tell from what you don’t see is that you exist in this space with no direction. It’s interesting that in pitch black we are consciously aware of ourselves and nothing else but when we sleep and have dreams we become very unaware of our own being until we can lucid dream. In a sense white is everything. If you shine light in something it has color. If you shine an extremely bright light on anything it would look white. So as black is absence white is creation and existence. In a poetic way a person in a dark room is the white because our own consciousness of ourselves intensifies the emptiness around us but also the awareness of ourselves. Like a light at the far end of an unlit highway at 11pm.

Before finishing the first minute of  the video I would say that a game is any activity that allows us to engage in using our brain in a different way than we would going throughout our day. After all a game comes with a goal therefore your brain is constantly figuring out how to play that game better and making little adjustments until eventually you get so used to swiping that it no longer matters how fast temple run goes. You just play until you’re board and once you’re board it’s no longer an engaging activity and you need a different game. Just like walking. When we learn to walk and run our body has to have that sense to balance our shift in weight until eventually we don’t even worry about falling anymore and if we start to we immediately know how to adjust and some people go to the next level with sports that require agility or incredible balance like figure skating or maybe dancing. I think games just a way exercise the brain and our human itch to compete wether it be against ourself, others, or the terms out in front of us like a diamond block behind a creeper and skeleton on the other side of a lava lake in Minecraft. Challenge Accepted. And then our brain just kicks into strategy mode if we decide to focus on the goal. So really any activity that you don’t do instinctively can’t be turned into a game if that’s what you decide to do. For example running is not a game. It’s a sport but humans can already run when they need to so it’s not engaging unless you buy stipulations on it that don’t necessarily have to accompany running like racing to a certain point. Just because you run doesn’t mean you know where you’re going so you can’t compete as if it’s a game but once you lie down the frame work as to what you are competing for then that’s what leads to you trying to figure out how to do it the best you need to in order to get the desired outcome. In humans the staring game is a game although humans look at things all the time we don’t willingly focus on staring longer than someone else for the most part. If you played the staring game with a dog you would be the only one playing because that dog has no idea what it’s apart of but the fact that you’re doing that for entertainment is what makes it a game for you and not for the dog. If you play tug of war with a dog then most people are actually playing a different game. We are trying to get the dog as excited as we can because we think that’s fun. The dog is trying to get the toy. If we were playing tug of war it wouldn’t be much of a game because most humans can hold on to whatever it is no matter what the dog does and all it takes for us is a quick hard yank and the dog loses. That’s not very engaging at all. That’s like saying the goal of the rain game is to get wet by rain. That’s going to happen already. This isn’t a very coherent point Im making and I feel like it could’ve been simpler but this is a comment not a essay for my professor. People don’t have to get it. The way I see the definition of words is "Common Usage." The way a word is used commonly is its main definition. But then there are secondary definitions used in smaller groups rather than the general group. Think of the word "Theory." It's used differently between common usage and scientific usage. The word Capitalist once mean "a rich business owner" and today, many communist circles still use this definition when the rest of society uses it to mean "one who believes in the economic system of capitalism." Gay used to only mean Happy...until it didn't. Language is extremely malleable and when people try to pin it down, they can run into problems such as it becoming outdated or even being dropped or a new word being added with the same definition. Language is subjective and in any debate/argument/discussion, if your words aren't defined the same, you can run into a lot of problems.

I think most have pondered the possibility that our internal definitions of colors may be different than others', but objects seem pretty objective, not subjective.  When you referenced a beetle & then a fox, the charicatures used to depict those matched with what i know to be a fox or a beetle, so i think that's debunked.  Colors could still be on the table, but then wouldn't we have an entire world of art, clothing, wall colors, etc., that doesn't quite "match"?  Some people obviously are literally & figuratively color blind, but the majority of the world agrees on whether certain combinations match or not.  If one's definition of black is actually magenta to soneone else but their definition of red is the same, then what one perceives as "matching" colors would be non-matching to the other.  This is rarely the case, which suggests that, scientifically,  we all do, in fact, perceive colors in a similar fashion.  This is within a certain spectrum, of course, because the wave nature of light itself demands that we define colors within a band of wavelengths (in nanometers for color).  Since no one can perceive a difference of one nanometer with the human eye alone, there is obviously a ln acceptable "range" for what we define as a specific color.

Meaning just happens to be another abstraction of reality. It doesn't matter what we call bananas or chom choms. The word refers to the same abstraction of reality. It would be much more inefficient to define a banana by all of what constitutes its existence such as: its relation to other bodies, all of its atoms and properties that relate to all other properties of other matter, including how it will change in the next instance. All things that hold meaning refer to reality in some way or another. But even this definition if someone put in the effort to devise such a definition would only pertain to the most we know what constitutes reality. We wouldn't be able to devise a definition of all of reality.

Either way calling something a banana holds enough meaning that it is a commonly sold and bought item which provides value to many people who like to eat bananas or do whatever else with one...

'HOW DO WORDS - A COLLECTION OF SOUNDS OR SYMBOLS - KEY INTO THE MENTAL CONCEPTS THAT WE WANT TO COMMUNICATE?'

Gotlab #friege

Reference - noun -of a word is the object or concept of a word is mean to designate

Sense - noun - The sense of a word is the way in which the words tie us to the object or concept

A #definition is traditionally understood as whatever meets the conditions for #necessity and #sufficiency

Necessary condition - noun - what#s needs - what must be present in order for a thing X to be thing X.

Sufficient condition - noun - something that is enough for x to be x but not required for that thing to meet that definition.

definition - find the criteria that exclude all non X's but include all X's


Ludwig Wittgenstein - Rigid definitions of a set no always possible - Everyone can provide a counter example - not a problem as we learn the meaning of words by hearing the way other members of our linguistic community use them. Our brains piece together a family resemblance based on what is common to all the senses of game we hear used - pattern recognitions

Words definitions rather than rigid definitions are cluster concepts.

cluster concepts - there is no one element that one thing in the cluster has in common but they all share something with other members of the group.

not every concept in the cluster is equal - some concepts a paradigm characteristics - central in the cluster - things that most people include - whereas fringe cases many would exclude

'language is a living phenomenon and like most living things there is going to be change and variation'

meaning is use

Meaning may be tied to particular linguistic communities - and a community may not span all speakers of a language - idiolect

Language cannot be tied directly to an internal state - we have no access to the black box inside each other's heads

speaker meaning - what a speaker intends when hearing a word

Audience meaning - what an audience understands when hearing a word

If the point of language is communication our goal is for speaker meaning and audience meaning to match up

I believe your reading of Wittgenstein’s "beetle in a box" thought experiment is slightly misleading. Wittgenstein does not demonstrate meaningful linguistic reference to subjective experience (the color red, pain, or love) to be impossible. Rather he shows that a certain account of this reference is fallacious, namely the idea that words function as labels for inner states (as illustrated by his "beetle in a box.") The general possibility of words referring to subjective experience is, however, not called into question by Wittgenstein. For him, the (putative) philosophical problems with regard to this issue only show that when thinking and talking about these questions, we are bewitched by the linguistic concepts we use (for example by the idea of an "inner" and an "outer".)
Nevertheless, great video (and series)!

That's nice and all but I feel like it's not necessary:
What if 'game' and 'game' are two homonyms, just like 'like' appreciate and 'like' similar, except that both are nouns; instead of a verb and an adverb.
there could be many words spelled 'game': 1) Something considered fun (at least by the speaker) which implies some degree of inter activeness, either with an object, another player, a set of rules, etc. 2) A contest between two or more parties with the objective of determining who is the luckiest / the best at a given task.
Moreover, the introduction of figurative language removes the need for extended meanings. Perhaps when they say "game of thrones", they don't mean an actual game, but rather that there is a contest for a position (throne), and that the players display carelessness for the consequences of their actions just as if it was "a game", underlining their psychopathic nature.
So, here's what I think should be the basis of programming syntax understanding AI:
- Words have a denotative meaning, sometimes several different ones (homonyms). Use context to find which one is the most likely.
- Words have a subjective connotative meaning that participates in delivering the emotional content of the message. To read emotional content, just take the 3 most significant words of the sentence and rate them for "anger", "sadness", "professionalism", "disgust", "affection"... etc.
- Words can be used to mean something else than the denotative meaning. If the sentence makes no sense literally because of a word, use context to find what is the intended meaning as if the word was missing, then apply the connotation of the figurative word to the intended meaning.

Programming double-entendre would be a bigger challenge.

Finally! Someone who recognizes how crazy language is! The fact we can speak to one another is positively straight up insane. The more you look into it, the crazier it gets. Although I would dispute the idea that we can't know that our subjective experiences are the same, but I don't believe I could reach the level of proving it. Brains are not as different as most would suppose. And our senses directly imprint our experience of reality on our brains in ways which do not differ much. When you see an "A", there is a literal pattern of neurons exactly in the shape of an "A" which light up. That's just where the optic nerve connects, and it gets more complicated from there, but I think that suggests that the chances our subjective experiences differ significantly (at least for those of us raised in similar environments) are small.

Back to how crazy language is, though. I say "apple" to you, and you picture an apple. I am able to project a pattern of neural activity into your brain. By vibrating meat parts in my mouth and throat. And you understand what I mean. Because when you were 2, someone made those noises a bunch of times when apples were around. And more generally because the people around you before age 5 frequently made similar noises when similar things were around. (A similar is VAGUE... sometimes a splatter of color on a piece of paper or a screen that has shapes kind-of like the thing you actually see (except flat, and at the wrong scale, and supporting none of the same interactions, and maybe even the totally wrong colors...) If they hadn't done that, then no amount of training could ever get you to understand that when I say "apple" I'm talking about a brand of computers. Obviously.

It seems to me that the definition of a "game" is a voluntary challenge. One can make one for oneself, or agree on one with selected others. It also seems to me that we can't talk about meanings of words in a general way--many technical words do have very specific meanings, while some of our most common words have fuzzy ones. Language is based upon agreement (as is art). Even in the midst of violent disagreement, our shared reality is vast, and the fact that we hang in there arguing for hours attests to this. While there are subjective and objective aspects to the words we use, it's our intention (or lack of) to understand each other that makes language work (or not).

This interpretation is decent but not 100% true. The best way to evaluate your experience against someone else's tend to vary from case to case but mostly fall into the category of empirical or textural. Empirical is easier to understand because you can do things like measure brainwaves in response to a certain concept or measure people's external reactions to those concepts giving away that a similar process has happened internally. Textural is more difficult to understand. You can use ideas like "the taste equivalent of the way a spaceship looks" and at a high level without thinking of the specific qualities of that thing people will often recognize the connection between the emotional response to that concept and the emotional response the this stimuli. This is often explored in media but not particularly well and it tends to be shallow or not very descriptive, since it is some connection you can only make having an experience and media tends to involve the simulation or imagination of experiences which won't trigger quite the same state of mind as actually living it. This presumably works by the way similar brain structures have formed to connect experiences linked in abstract ways and so might elude to the fact that our experiences at least with many people can be shown to be either similar or dissimilar.

A "Chomsky" is someone who proposes a political philosophy devoid of over-arching structure where people are free to enjoy their "chom choms" any damn way they want.  Of course, this structural vacuum could itself be considered as a form of structure and people may eventually feel that there is something implicitly suspect in any system of political thought in which there exists no prescribed process through which to enjoy their chom choms.  A "Noam Chomsky" is a linguist and political philosopher who could explain all of this without so much wasteful hyperbole and who is demonstratively fond of anarchism; just such a free-wheeling political philosophy as would have you unbound to prescribed methods of chom chom appreciation.  Noam Chomsky became famous through his theories of pre-existing neurophysiological structures upon and from which language develops in human beings.  The curious dissonance between a preponderance towards a  political theory (Anarchism) which subverts overarching structure and a belief in a pre-existing structure in the brain which preconditions human linguistic development seems to imply that Noam Chomsky is most certainly a Chomsky but may (or may not) be several chom choms short of a bunch.

Use is absolutely meaning. Technical industries, such as utilities, use a variety of terms to mean something completely different for that technical linguistic community than it would for the general public. And what's even weirder is that those terms transcend their language to other languages. For example: a "DOG HOUSE" in a pressurized water reactor nuclear utility may refer to a high pressure turbine located on the "housing"; and not a place where a dog lives. It doesn't resemble a "dog house" in the slightest. And what's even weirder is that the same term is used in France. Not in French, but in English! as in Turbine Doghouse avec radiateur, sans chauffage.

There is a problem with creating a word and assigning a meaning for which is already covered by a well used word. As it was presented, there is no context for why that word should go with the meaning. For a word to come into existence it must be necessary, and I can't see that being the case here. If you reversed it, and looked at how bananas refers to the fruit and a colloquialism for being crazy - I've not checked, but there must be some context for that adoption. Furthermore, creation of a word would still likely follow some broad conventions of syllable use in the given language (English) and as an Australian, chom chom doesn't feel natural in how it resonates with the idea of the object it refers to.

I ecpected that you mention the language bias as well. To the individual box there's also a cultural box. You'll see it when you learn a new language and notice that some words have many synonyms and related words (e.g. money, boobs, butts, sand, ice) whereas you have only one word for it in your language and other words from your language cannot be translated directly (coolness, Treppenwitz, Tsundere...). It reveals that languages have different interests or preferences (the more synonyms a word has the more important it tends to be).

To sucessfully invent a new word, it should simplify an old word or give a name to a previously unnamed concept. Technically, we all decide as individuals what words mean, the problem arises when you start using a word or a phrase in a way that most people do not use it, is that most people will no longer know what you mean.

For instance, changing the meanings of privilege and sexism and racism to mean even the slightest of minutia devalues the meaning of the word, until it no longer applies to a very specific thing, and is instead a broad concept that can be applied to anything if you try hard enough.

When you use these words to mean things they dont mean, it may be accurate to you, but it is not accurate to reality or how everyone else describes those words or those things.

A game is an exercise in skill or intelligence usually with a winner or at least a win condition to strive for, sometimes timed, sometimes not. A game is also generally a non real life condition, tic tac toe is a game, but has no applicable real life counterpart.

call of duty is a game, and while war exists, the depicted events IN the game, are fictional, and do not have a real life counterpart.

Monopoly is based on a loose economy, but is generally not accurate enough to real life to be anything other than a simulated experience emulating a real world experience, with a win condition and a lose condition.

The difference between a game and real life is; a game is not taken seriously. Even when you take a game seriously, like competitions, tournaments, and olympics, it is still not a serious matter.

In analytic linguistics, we learned about something like the beetle in a box, except in regards to grammar instead of words. We learned that there are three types of grammar in languages.
1. Prescriptive (grammar that you get taught in school and is taught formally)
2. Descriptive (grammar that a linguistic community uses that follows rules that aren't immediately apparent - just being used to describe things that at least one other person recognizes)
3. Mental. This is the grammar that actually lies in people's minds and can't be expressed without relying on descriptive grammar. It's the jumble of thoughts that we somehow order to have meaning to us, but the second we produce it (even by thinking with words) we start using descriptive grammar.

The most important thing we learned is that language doesn't work top-down. It's not a prescripted system that is taught to people and they internalize. It starts mental, becomes descriptive, and then snobbish folks decide to write a dictionary on its "rules."

I object to the claim (at 8:00) that "the whole point of language is communication". I think communication is almost certainly the primary point of language, but is not its whole point. Language is also very useful for information storage (not just information transmission, which is what communication is) and also for abstractification, which allows us to think in abstract terms rather than only in concrete ones. Not every symbol is linguistic, but most are, and onomatopoeia are basically the only words that come even half-way close to not being symbolic representations of something other than themselves.

A really excellent introduction to semantics! The only point I'd wish was covered, though so much was covered it's easy to see why it might not have been, is the inability to perfectly translate meaning between languages. If meaning is defined by language communities, then there are no objective definitions to pin words down universally with. What I call "leg" in my linguistic community is a limb segment going from my hip to my ankle excluding my foot, while in another linguistic community the word that gets translated to mean "leg" includes the foot or can even be used to refer exclusively to the foot and not the limb it's attached to, while "hip" is used to mean buttox, not the highest point of the joint that limb is attached to.

Which probably sounds really pointless and academic, but it's really important for at least two reasons: 1) it means that computer translation is almost always going to be imperfect for translating between historically-separated language communities, and 2) it means that the ways we take for granted for how the world is defined and organized are really far more culture-bound than most people realize.

Speaking of language, does language make culture? Is culture society? I see 1871 Germany's annexation of Alsace-Lorraine, Nazi Germany's annexation of Sudetenland, and even the 2014 annexation of Crimea by Russia, all on the backs of some commonality in language as a test for culture/nationality. Noticeably, my top 3 examples are arguably despotic, but these language-based nationalistic accumulations don't seem flawed on the exterior, except, of course, that they remove self-determination as the primary mechanism of nationality. At first I think of English, but I don't see the UK trying to rebuild its empire on the backs of every english speaking nation in the world. Same with France. Though, I doubt England will look fondly on Scotland when they try to separate and stay in the EU (i foresee arguments of common language and culture to persuade them). So I come back to: is language the foundational basis of culture and thus nationality? Reflexively, I say no. But that may be my American [multi-cultural loving] bias showing. Other places in the world revere their language (France), and all that it entails.

The real question is: if one small part of a language community starts using words in a way that the rest of the language community would say violates their meaning, and that erroneous usage grows more and more widespread despite the continued insistence by people who were using the words first that they continue to mean what they used to mean, does there ever come a point where the erroneous usage ceases to be in error?

(The answer is no, but this use-is-meaning definition fails to address the problem at all, and superficially would have the consequence that there's no such thing as an error in language, because if someone's doing it, it's OK).

Can we create meaning? Well, I'll just skip the 1700-or-so words the Bard of Avon created, and go to a much more recent, though a bit more sexual example*. In 2001 Dan Savage did a poll in his Savage Love advice column to make an expression for a certain sexual activity involving strap-on dildos. The winner was "pegging", and guess what? It stuck. It may not have been included in any official dictionaries yet, but search for the term on Google and all the first-page hits will be about the sexual activity, not about any of the other definitions of the word, like to fix a price or attach something to something else with pegs (at least in my google search).

*Well... a fair amount of those 1700 words were rather dirty, as well, I guess.

I mean, you guys have made a lot of fantastic courses, but I think this is one of the most comprehensive and accessible guides to Philosophy available anywhere. You take 45 minute lectures and break them down into 10-minute videos, while still--somewhat miraculously--showing the nuance and complications embedded within each argument.
